chapterSummary.General: Genesis 19 details the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah. Two angels arrive in Sodom and are reluctantly hosted by Lot. The men of the city surround Lot's house, demanding to rape the visitors. Lot offers his daughters instead, but the mob persists. The angels rescue Lot, strike the attackers blind, and urge Lot to flee with his family as judgment is imminent. Lot hesitates but is dragged out with his wife and daughters, warned not to look back. He negotiates to flee to the nearby town of Zoar. As God rains down burning sulfur on Sodom and Gomorrah, Lot's wife looks back and becomes a pillar of salt. Abraham witnesses the destruction from afar. The chapter ends with a disturbing epilogue: Lot and his daughters dwell in a cave; believing they are the only survivors, the daughters get Lot drunk on consecutive nights and conceive children by him, resulting in the births of Moab and Ben-Ammi, the ancestors of the Moabites and Ammonites.

1.Non-Denominational: The two angels (who had left Abraham) arrive at Sodom in the evening as Lot is sitting in the gateway of the city. Lot sees them, rises to meet them, and bows down respectfully.
1.General: The two angels (who had left Abraham) arrive at Sodom in the evening as Lot is sitting in the gateway of the city. Lot sees them, rises to meet them, and bows down respectfully.

2.Non-Denominational: Lot urges the visitors to stay at his house, offering hospitality (washing feet, spending the night). They initially decline, intending to stay in the square, but Lot insists strongly, and they agree to go to his house.
2.General: Lot urges the visitors to stay at his house, offering hospitality (washing feet, spending the night). They initially decline, intending to stay in the square, but Lot insists strongly, and they agree to go to his house.

3.Non-Denominational: Lot prepares a meal for them, including baking bread without yeast, and they eat.
3.General: Lot prepares a meal for them, including baking bread without yeast, and they eat.

4.Non-Denominational: Before they lie down for the night, all the men of Sodom, both young and old, from every part of the city, surround Lot's house.
4.General: Before they lie down for the night, all the men of Sodom, both young and old, from every part of the city, surround Lot's house.

5.Non-Denominational: They call out to Lot, demanding he bring out the visitors so they can have sex with them (gang rape).
5.General: They call out to Lot, demanding he bring out the visitors so they can have sex with them (gang rape).

6.Non-Denominational: Lot goes outside to confront the mob, shutting the door behind him to protect his guests.
6.General: Lot goes outside to confront the mob, shutting the door behind him to protect his guests.

7.Non-Denominational: He pleads with the men not to act so wickedly.
7.General: He pleads with the men not to act so wickedly.

8.Non-Denominational: In a desperate and morally reprehensible attempt to appease the mob and protect his guests under the code of hospitality, Lot offers his two virgin daughters to the men instead.
8.General: In a desperate and morally reprehensible attempt to appease the mob and protect his guests under the code of hospitality, Lot offers his two virgin daughters to the men instead.

9.Non-Denominational: The mob rejects Lot's offer, insulting him as a foreigner setting himself up as a judge, and threatening to treat him worse than his guests. They surge forward to break down the door.
9.General: The mob rejects Lot's offer, insulting him as a foreigner setting himself up as a judge, and threatening to treat him worse than his guests. They surge forward to break down the door.

10.Non-Denominational: The angelic visitors reach out, pull Lot back into the house, and shut the door.
10.General: The angelic visitors reach out, pull Lot back into the house, and shut the door.

11.Non-Denominational: The angels strike the men outside (young and old) with blindness, so they cannot find the door.
11.General: The angels strike the men outside (young and old) with blindness, so they cannot find the door.

12.Non-Denominational: The angels reveal their mission to Lot, asking if he has any other relatives (sons-in-law, sons, daughters) in the city, instructing him to get them out because they are going to destroy the place.
12.General: The angels reveal their mission to Lot, asking if he has any other relatives (sons-in-law, sons, daughters) in the city, instructing him to get them out because they are going to destroy the place.

13.Non-Denominational: They explain the outcry against Sodom's people is so great before the Lord that He has sent them to destroy it.
13.General: They explain the outcry against Sodom's people is so great before the Lord that He has sent them to destroy it.

14.Non-Denominational: Lot goes out to speak to his sons-in-law (who were pledged to marry his daughters), warning them to flee because the Lord is about to destroy the city. However, they think he is joking.
14.General: Lot goes out to speak to his sons-in-law (who were pledged to marry his daughters), warning them to flee because the Lord is about to destroy the city. However, they think he is joking.

15.Non-Denominational: At daybreak, the angels urge Lot to hurry, telling him to take his wife and two daughters to avoid being swept away in the city's punishment.
15.General: At daybreak, the angels urge Lot to hurry, telling him to take his wife and two daughters to avoid being swept away in the city's punishment.

16.Non-Denominational: When Lot hesitates, the angels grasp his hand and the hands of his wife and daughters and lead them safely out of the city, showing the Lord's mercy.
16.General: When Lot hesitates, the angels grasp his hand and the hands of his wife and daughters and lead them safely out of the city, showing the Lord's mercy.

17.Non-Denominational: Once outside, one angel commands them to flee for their lives, not to look back, and not to stop anywhere in the plain, but to escape to the mountains to avoid destruction.
17.General: Once outside, one angel commands them to flee for their lives, not to look back, and not to stop anywhere in the plain, but to escape to the mountains to avoid destruction.

18.Non-Denominational: Lot pleads with the angels (addressing them as 'Lords').
18.General: Lot pleads with the angels (addressing them as 'Lords').

19.Non-Denominational: He acknowledges their favor but expresses fear that he cannot reach the mountains before disaster overtakes him.
19.General: He acknowledges their favor but expresses fear that he cannot reach the mountains before disaster overtakes him.

20.Non-Denominational: Lot points to a small town nearby (Zoar) and asks permission to flee there instead, arguing its small size makes it insignificant.
20.General: Lot points to a small town nearby (Zoar) and asks permission to flee there instead, arguing its small size makes it insignificant.

21.Non-Denominational: The angel grants Lot's request, agreeing not to overthrow the town of Zoar where he flees.
21.General: The angel grants Lot's request, agreeing not to overthrow the town of Zoar where he flees.

22.Non-Denominational: The angel urges Lot to hurry to Zoar, stating they cannot act until he reaches it. (This is why the town was called Zoar, meaning 'small').
22.General: The angel urges Lot to hurry to Zoar, stating they cannot act until he reaches it. (This is why the town was called Zoar, meaning 'small').

23.Non-Denominational: By the time Lot reaches Zoar, the sun had risen over the land.
23.General: By the time Lot reaches Zoar, the sun had risen over the land.

24.Non-Denominational: The Lord rains down burning sulfur on Sodom and Gomorrah—from the Lord out of the heavens.
24.General: The Lord rains down burning sulfur on Sodom and Gomorrah—from the Lord out of the heavens.

25.Non-Denominational: God overthrows those cities and the entire plain, destroying all inhabitants and the vegetation.
25.General: God overthrows those cities and the entire plain, destroying all inhabitants and the vegetation.

26.Non-Denominational: Lot's wife looks back (disobeying the command) and becomes a pillar of salt.
26.General: Lot's wife looks back (disobeying the command) and becomes a pillar of salt.

27.Non-Denominational: Early the next morning, Abraham goes to the place where he had stood before the Lord (during his intercession).
27.General: Early the next morning, Abraham goes to the place where he had stood before the Lord (during his intercession).

28.Non-Denominational: Abraham looks down toward Sodom and Gomorrah and the plain and sees dense smoke rising from the land, like smoke from a furnace.
28.General: Abraham looks down toward Sodom and Gomorrah and the plain and sees dense smoke rising from the land, like smoke from a furnace.

29.Non-Denominational: The text clarifies that when God destroyed the cities of the plain, He remembered Abraham and brought Lot out of the catastrophe that overthrew the cities where Lot had lived.
29.General: The text clarifies that when God destroyed the cities of the plain, He remembered Abraham and brought Lot out of the catastrophe that overthrew the cities where Lot had lived.

30.Non-Denominational: Lot leaves Zoar, afraid to stay there, and settles in the mountains with his two daughters, living in a cave.
30.General: Lot leaves Zoar, afraid to stay there, and settles in the mountains with his two daughters, living in a cave.

31.Non-Denominational: The older daughter says to the younger that their father is old, and there are no other men around to continue the family line according to custom.
31.General: The older daughter says to the younger that their father is old, and there are no other men around to continue the family line according to custom.

32.Non-Denominational: She proposes they get their father drunk with wine and then lie with him to preserve their family line.
32.General: She proposes they get their father drunk with wine and then lie with him to preserve their family line.

33.Non-Denominational: That night, they get Lot drunk, and the older daughter sleeps with him. Lot is unaware of when she lay down or when she got up.
33.General: That night, they get Lot drunk, and the older daughter sleeps with him. Lot is unaware of when she lay down or when she got up.

34.Non-Denominational: The next day, the older daughter tells the younger what she did and suggests the younger sister do the same that night.
34.General: The next day, the older daughter tells the younger what she did and suggests the younger sister do the same that night.

35.Non-Denominational: They get Lot drunk again that night, and the younger daughter sleeps with him. Again, Lot is unaware.
35.General: They get Lot drunk again that night, and the younger daughter sleeps with him. Again, Lot is unaware.

36.Non-Denominational: Both of Lot's daughters become pregnant by their father.
36.General: Both of Lot's daughters become pregnant by their father.

37.Non-Denominational: The older daughter gives birth to a son and names him Moab; he is the ancestor of the Moabites.
37.General: The older daughter gives birth to a son and names him Moab; he is the ancestor of the Moabites.

38.Non-Denominational: The younger daughter also gives birth to a son and names him Ben-Ammi; he is the ancestor of the Ammonites.
38.General: The younger daughter also gives birth to a son and names him Ben-Ammi; he is the ancestor of the Ammonites.
